headline: UK rolls out free AI training, but will it save your job?
summary: Free artificial intelligence training is being made available to everyone in the UK as the government steps up efforts to prepare the workforce for rapid technological change.  From today, adults can access short, practical courses through the government's upgraded AI Skills Hub, designed to help people use AI tools in the workplace.  The training covers everyday tasks such as drafting text, creating content, and automating administrative work - with some courses taking less than 20 minutes to complete.

raw.headline: UK rolls out free AI training, but will it save your job?
raw.summary: Free artificial intelligence training is being made available to everyone in the UK as the government steps up efforts to prepare the workforce for rapid technological change.  From today, adults can access short, practical courses through the government's upgraded AI Skills Hub, designed to help people use AI tools in the workplace.  The training covers everyday tasks such as drafting text, creating content, and automating administrative work - with some courses taking less than 20 minutes to complete.

headline: The Weather is Freezing but Stocks Are Hot. It’s the January Effect.
summary: With the U.S. digging out from Winter Storm Fern, and counting the cost of an arctic blast that could bring record cold readings as far south as the Florida Keys, investors are also taking the temperature of perhaps the most important stretch of the year for the stock market.  Labeled the “January Barometer” by famed academic Yale Hirsch, creator of the Stock Trader’s Almanac, the idea of extrapolating first- month returns over the calendar year has proven to be a winner.  Adam Turnquist, chief technical strategist at  LPL Financial  notes data showing that since 1950, the  has generated an average return of nearly 17% in years when the benchmark ends January in positive territory.

raw.headline: The Weather is Freezing but Stocks Are Hot. It’s the January Effect.
raw.summary: With the U.S. digging out from Winter Storm Fern, and counting the cost of an arctic blast that could bring record cold readings as far south as the Florida Keys, investors are also taking the temperature of perhaps the most important stretch of the year for the stock market.  Labeled the “January Barometer” by famed academic Yale Hirsch, creator of the Stock Trader’s Almanac, the idea of extrapolating first- month returns over the calendar year has proven to be a winner.  Adam Turnquist, chief technical strategist at  LPL Financial  notes data showing that since 1950, the  has generated an average return of nearly 17% in years when the benchmark ends January in positive territory.

headline: Microsoft’s New AI Chip Can’t Keep Nvidia Stock Down
summary: Nvidia  stock was rising early Tuesday even as  Microsoft  revealed the use of its own artificial-intelligence chip.  The focus for the week is on earnings from Microsoft and  Meta Platforms  both big customers of Nvidia.  “Maia 200 is…the most efficient inference system Microsoft has ever deployed, with 30% better performance per dollar than the latest generation hardware in our fleet today,” said Scott Guthrie, executive vice president of the Microsoft Cloud and AI Group, in a statement.

headline: Big Tech earnings to test AI rally as resurgent Alphabet takes lead
summary: STORY: Microsoft and Meta will kick off Big Tech earnings this week under pressure to prove their costly bets on AI can power another year of strong growth.That's as a resurgent Alphabet takes the lead in the high-stakes race.The companies, along with Amazon, are expected to lift their AI spending this year by 30% to more than $500 billion.It's an unprecedented outlay that will sharpen investor scrutiny.Some have expressed doubts over whether Microsoft squandered a first-mover advantage in AI it secured through its OpenAI investment.Meta too is under pressure to show payoffs from its expensive push into superintelligence.Both stocks declined more than 6% in the last three months of 2025.While Amazon saw a small 5% gain after its November deal with OpenAI signaled that the largest cloud-computing provider in the U.S. was no longer behind on AI.Alphabet shares though surged about 29% in that period.It followed a strong reception of Google's latest Gemini 3 model.The company also recently struck a deal to power Apple's revamped Siri.LSEG data showed that in the October-December quarter, Google Cloud revenue growth likely quickened to 35% from 33.5% in the previous three months.But doubts linger about the real-world benefits for the businesses adopting the technology.And feeding into bubble fears that hounded the technology industry for much of last year.

raw.headline: Big Tech earnings to test AI rally as resurgent Alphabet takes lead
raw.summary: STORY: Microsoft and Meta will kick off Big Tech earnings this week under pressure to prove their costly bets on AI can power another year of strong growth.That's as a resurgent Alphabet takes the lead in the high-stakes race.The companies, along with Amazon, are expected to lift their AI spending this year by 30% to more than $500 billion.It's an unprecedented outlay that will sharpen investor scrutiny.Some have expressed doubts over whether Microsoft squandered a first-mover advantage in AI it secured through its OpenAI investment.Meta too is under pressure to show payoffs from its expensive push into superintelligence.Both stocks declined more than 6% in the last three months of 2025.While Amazon saw a small 5% gain after its November deal with OpenAI signaled that the largest cloud-computing provider in the U.S. was no longer behind on AI.Alphabet shares though surged about 29% in that period.It followed a strong reception of Google's latest Gemini 3 model.The company also recently struck a deal to power Apple's revamped Siri.LSEG data showed that in the October-December quarter, Google Cloud revenue growth likely quickened to 35% from 33.5% in the previous three months.But doubts linger about the real-world benefits for the businesses adopting the technology.And feeding into bubble fears that hounded the technology industry for much of last year.

headline: Prodoscore Q4 2025 Data Shows Employee AI Usage Increases Productivity Across U.S. Workforces

The report presents data from over 9,000 employees across 176 companies, spanning 80 job roles and 10 industries. headline: Meta signs deal to pay Corning up to $6 billion for fiber-optic cables, CNBC reports
summary: Facebook parent Meta Platforms has signed a deal to pay Gorilla Glass maker Corning up to $6 ​billion through 2030 for fiber-optic cables in its AI ‌data centers, CNBC reported on Tuesday.  The company expects AI hyperscalers, including Meta, Amazon, ‌Alphabet's Google and Microsoft, to be its biggest customers next year, the report said, citing an interview with Corning CEO Wendell Weeks.  Corning's optical connectivity products are among key components required to support the ⁠massive computing and data ‌transmission demands at data centers.

raw.headline: Meta signs deal to pay Corning up to $6 billion for fiber-optic cables, CNBC reports

The company expects AI hyperscalers, including Meta, Amazon, ‌Alphabet's Google and Microsoft, to be its biggest customers next year, the report said, citing an interview with Corning CEO Wendell Weeks.  Corning's optical connectivity products are among key components required to support the ⁠massive computing and data ‌transmission demands at data centers.

headline: Latest News In Cloud AI - EU AI GRID Advances Europe's Digital Sovereignty Initiative
summary: The EU AI GRID has been launched in Vilnius, marking a significant advancement in AI infrastructure within Europe. This initiative, spearheaded by Telecentras and Singapore-based Embedded LLM, aims to provide a network that complies with GDPR data and the EU AI Act, ensuring digital sovereignty and protection of sensitive information. The project is designed to empower AI users in Europe with transparency and robust data protection, thereby enhancing productivity and security. The EU AI GRID...

headline: Stocks and Gold Near Record Highs? Maybe It’s About Trust and Verify.
summary: “Trust but verify,” a Russian proverb famously used by President Ronald Reagan during nuclear disarmament negotiations with the former Soviet Union, feels like an apt description of global investor sentiment toward U.S. markets.  Stocks are poised to test new all-time highs again this week amid a parade of corporate earnings updates likely to consolidate forecasts of double-digit profit growth again this year, and a Federal Reserve interest rate decision that is likely to clear the way for further borrowing cost reductions over the next 12 months.

headline: Tesla’s Price Target Is Rising Even as Its Profit Outlook Tanks
summary: “Tesla is truly unique in capital markets,” said Nicholas Colas, co-founder at DataTrek Research.  Over the past 12 months, the average forecast for Tesla’s 2026 net income has tumbled 56% from $14.1 billion to $6.1 billion.  The stock is up 7% in that time after closing Tuesday at $435.20, well above Wall Street’s expectations for a year from now.

headline: How 175-year-old glass company Corning won a $6 billion AI infrastructure deal with Meta
summary: Meta is giving Corning up to $6 billion for fiber-optic cable in its AI data centers, in a deal reported first by CNBC. Famous for making iPhone glass for Apple, the 175-year-old U.S. company is now seeing record fiber demand and its stock rose 75% in a year. CNBC went to North Carolina for an exclusive interview with Corning CEO Wendell Weeks about a new type of optical fiber invented for AI, and saw the expansion that Corning says will make its Hickory cable factory the largest in the world.

raw.headline: How 175-year-old glass company Corning won a $6 billion AI infrastructure deal with Meta
raw.summary: Meta is giving Corning up to $6 billion for fiber-optic cable in its AI data centers, in a deal reported first by CNBC. Famous for making iPhone glass for Apple, the 175-year-old U.S. company is now seeing record fiber demand and its stock rose 75% in a year. CNBC went to North Carolina for an exclusive interview with Corning CEO Wendell Weeks about a new type of optical fiber invented for AI, and saw the expansion that Corning says will make its Hickory cable factory the largest in the world.
